Posts.Content: SueB46 wrote: It's been 6 months since my last chemo and my hair is coming in so slowly - it's about 2 inches long now. My eyebrows are about 1/3 of where they were. This is so depressing. I want to get back to "normal"! Can anyone suggest a vitamin supplement or something to promote growth? Sue Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Help With Slow Hair Regrowth SueB46 unlimited

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 09:06PM SueB46 wrote: Sassa - No, I'm not on herceptin. Terry - I thought growth rate was about 1/2" per month. I got mine colored last week too, but I still hate how it looks. I'll check out Nioxin. I think another one I've read about on here is Biotin. I'm so sick of looking like a man! Sue
Posts.Title: Help With Slow Hair Regrowth SueB46 unlimited

Posts.Content: SueB46 wrote: It's been four months since my last chemo. My hair is about 1 3/4" long but looks awful! It really does look like roadkill. You know, mottled color, dull, sticking up here and there, matted down everywhere else. Can a sylist do something with this? I definitely need a coloring, but don't know if a trim will help. Maybe I just have to wait for it to get a little longer. And what's with my eyebrows!? My eyelashes are all there, I'm shaving my legs again, but my eyebrows don't want to make the effort. I'd say they got to about half the hair necessary for full eyebrows, then stopped - so I still have to fill in with pencil. I'm wondering if they'll ever come back. Sue Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 4 Months Later - Sparse Eyebrows & Roadkill Hair SueB46 abbadoodles

Posts.Content: SueB46 wrote: I finished 4 A/C and 4 Taxotere, pre-surgery. My last Taxotere treatment was on 10/18. A little over a week ago I developed edema in both feet and ankles. They are so swollen it's difficult to walk. Have had ultrasound of legs, EKG and heart utrasound. Everything is fine. I'm on 20 mg. Lasix, but so far no help. Anyone else develop edema? I'm 47, but feel 87! Sue Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Terribly Swollen Feet & Ankles SueB46 meliaanne

Posts.Content: SueB46 wrote: Hi Everyone. I went through 4 A/C followed by 4 Taxotere. Had my last treatment 10/18. The treatment before, it took me the entire three weeks to recover and still wasn't close to 100% for the last one. Now I have surgery scheduled for 11/19. I was really hoping to get some recovery time in between, maybe 8 weeks. Both the scheduling nurse and my husband pushed me to take the first available date. I'm so worried about this. I'll be asking my med. onc. about it, but wondered what you all thought. Sue Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Finished chemo. Surgery so soon? SueB46 SueB46

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 09:34AM SueB46 wrote: Hi Jeanette, I did have my surgery as scheduled. Everything went well. Now I'm also glad I had it done when I did. At least it's behind me. As for Taxotere...besides the usual stuff you describe, I also developed very burning, aching leg muscles which are so cramped up when I get up in the a.m. it takes me a while to walk properly. I also have edema in my feet and ankles. I have an oncologist who doesn't seem to have any answers. Maybe it comes from the Neulasta. Apparently this reaction isn't common, so I'm sure you'll get through just fine. Most people have fewer side effects from Taxotere than from A/C. Best wishes. Sue
Posts.Title: Finished chemo. Surgery so soon? SueB46 SueB46

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2008 02:37PM SueB46 wrote: I'm almost through 6+ weeks of rads. No real fatigue so far. My skin looks awful - totally red, blistered, peeling - but surprisingly it isn't all that painful. Sue

Posts.Content: SueB46 wrote: Just wondering how long most of you had your drainage tube(s) in after surgery. Sue Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How Long Was Your Drainage Tube In? SueB46 Tina337

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 12:20PM SueB46 wrote: Mine is a bulb at the end of a long tube. It actually has a loop to put on a belt, so that's what I do. When showering, I tie a shoestring around my neck and hang it from there. Also, when I left the hospital I was told to go to a nearby shop that sells items for women with breast cancer. There I got a sort of camisole to wear under clothes that has breast forms and pockets for the drainage tubes. Insurance actually covered the cost of it. Sue
Posts.Title: How Long Was Your Drainage Tube In? SueB46 Tina337

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 10:25AM SueB46 wrote: Thanks everyone. I have one tube in and expected to have it removed about 7 days after surgery (which would have been yesterday). It's draining at under 20 cc in a 24 hr. period. Now it looks like it might be in another week because the doctor is away! But the nurse will "take a look" on Friday. I'm not real pleased. I really hate this thing! Thanks again for your input. Sue
Posts.Title: How Long Was Your Drainage Tube In? SueB46 Tina337
